<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 313, 386, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 356]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 358, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 373, 890, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 401, 382, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 430, 890, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 459, 890, 474]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 489, 555, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 518, 764, 532]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 533, 416, 547]]<|/det|>
Any working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 549, 359, 562]]<|/det|>

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
In an experiment to determine the Young modulus \(E\) of the material of a wire, the measurements taken are shown.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 115, 616, 214]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{rl} & \mathrm{mass~hung~on~end~of~wire}\qquad m = 2.300\pm 0.002\mathrm{kg}\\ & \mathrm{original~length~of~wire}\qquad l = 2.864\pm 0.005\mathrm{m}\\ & \mathrm{diameter~of~wire}\qquad d = 0.82\pm 0.01\mathrm{mm}\\ & \mathrm{extension~of~wire}\qquad e = 7.6\pm 0.2\mathrm{mm} \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 223, 443, 240]]<|/det|>
The Young modulus is calculated using

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[454, 255, 544, 289]]<|/det|>
\[E = \frac{4mg l}{\pi d^2 e}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 304, 432, 321]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 333, 494, 351]]<|/det|>
The calculated value of \(E\) is \(1.61 \times 10^{10} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 361, 704, 378]]<|/det|>
How should the calculated value of \(E\) and its uncertainty be expressed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 364, 408]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 417, 364, 435]]<|/det|>
B \((1.61 \pm 0.05) \times 10^{10} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 364, 462]]<|/det|>
C \((1.61 \pm 0.07) \times 10^{10} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 471, 364, 489]]<|/det|>
D \((1.61 \pm 0.09) \times 10^{10} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\)
